reviewText: One of the things I love about Kundalini Yoga is the use of the gong -- Ravi and Ana use it this DVD in very subtle but powerful ways, and I believe it helps me get out my mind and into the moment in a very big way.Also, according to Kundalini Yoga, strengthening your core helps you follow through on your will.Using the gong in conjunction with navel exercises is a powerful combo.  Thank you Tavi and Ana for offering this selection and the brilliance it took to create this very challenging, but effective DVD.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I hesitated to buy this one at first because I thought it might be too difficult for me. But I am so glad I did. The first time I did it I felt the burn for about two days afterward. I realized that I really needed this. My navel center has always been a little weak but the more I work on it the more powerful I feel ~ physically and mentally. This DVD makes me feel like I can do anything!!! I look forward to many more wonderful hours with this DVD and a much stronger outlook on myself and my life. Do not hesitate with this one like I did. I only wished I had bought it sooner. It really is a fabulous workout for the core muscles and your mental connection with yourself and the rest of the world. It really works you from the inside out.I use this one when I feel like I need more willpower. I also alternate it with some of the other ones that work the extremities a little more. That way, if my arms and legs are still sore I can still work out ~ just on a different area. (Then I feel sore from head to toe! LOL!)

reviewText: This is one of the earlier DVDs (released 2004) by husband-wife instructor team Ravi Singh and Ana Brett.  As with all of their DVDs, Ana alone is featured on screen modelling the exercises, but unlike with their newer DVDs, Ravi alone provides the voiceover instruction.  For those unfamiliar with Kundalini Yoga, is a distinct style which involves meditation, unique forms of breathing such as the breath of fire, and movement patterns combined with breath; there are few traditional yoga postures recognizable from hatha yoga practice.I have a chaptered version of this DVD (I believe that some of the older releases were NOT chaptered), and the Main Menu is listed as follows:*Play All*Tuning In*Warm-Ups*Navel Power*Navel Power - Part 2*Relaxation*Mantra MeditationI have broken down each segment below.TUNING IN (3 minutes)As with every Ravi & Ana DVD, they begin here with three repetitions of the chant "ong namu guru dev namu."  Ravi then provides instruction on meditating to the word of power "sat nam" throughout the practice.  (Note:  Ravi cues many breaks for both meditation and relaxation throughout the entire Navel Power routine.)WARM-UPS (25 minutes)First is a breathing exercise, breathing in to four counts (sa-ta-na-ma) and then out to one (wahe-guru).  Next Ana performs stomach grinds and spine flexes forward and back, then sits on her heels and repeats the spinal flexes.  This is followed by a held forearm plank with long deep breathing, then Ana returns to seated on heels for spinal flex with breath of fire (BOF).  Seated with her legs out straight, Ana moves forward and back.  Ravi then cues holding one leg with BOF.  The warm-ups conclude with slow repetitions of elevated bridge (about 3 minutes total).NAVEL POWER (29.5 minutes)Lying on the back, Ana starts here with slow bent leg crunches; this is followed by bent leg roll-ups.  Next, she holds elevated bridge with BOF.  Placing the hands under the glutes, Ana performs double leg lifts and then parallel bicycle.  Moving onto her stomach, she does cobra, bent-leg cobra hold, and bow pose with BOF.  She then returns to her back, raising her head and heels 6 inches and holding with BOF.  Again flipping onto her stomach, she raises all of her limbs (arms front) and holds with BOF.  At this point, Ravi cues Ana to stand for oblique twists (alternating hands to sternum), slow side bends, and slow standing backbend to forward bend.NAVEL POWER - PART 2 (16.5 minutes)At almost the one hour point into the routine, Ana repeats both the crunches and the bent leg roll-ups.  Just when it feels like the workout should be winding down, she holds wheel pose with BOF for about 1 minute (she suggests bridge pose as an alternate).  This is followed by parallel bicycle, this time adding BOF and rotation.  Next comes alternating leg lifts, and then, sitting on the heels, Sat Kriya performed for several minutes.  The final exercise involves scissoring the legs while leaning back on the elbows.RELAXATION (2.5 minutes)In this short segment, Ravi cues relaxing and letting go after all the work put into the practice.  He also introduces the meditation coming up in the next segment.MEDITATION (5 minutes)The meditation repeated here is har har har har wahe guru sat nam har haree, moving the hands in a pattern reaching up the body.  At the end of the meditation, Ravi and Ana conclude (as they always do) with a 1.5 minute sequence that includes a closing prayer (a positive wish for self, a healing prayer for someone who needs it, and a prayer for peace on earth), and then a conclusion with a long "sat" and a brief "nam."As usual, Ravi and Ana did a nice job with this DVD, although I did miss Ana joining Ravi for the narration.  I recognized many of the exercises from their other DVDs; in particular, much of this practice felt quite similar to the "Fight Fire with Fire" segment ofFat Free Yoga - Lose Weight & Feel Great.  But although I enjoyed this workout in some ways, my main problem with it is that, at a total time of 1 hour, 23 minutes, it felt VERY long.  While doing the warm-ups, I kept wondering when they would be over; 25 minutes for the warm-ups alone is much longer than most of the Ravi/Ana DVDs I have tried.  Furthermore, as noted above, the practice increases significantly in intensity AFTER the one-hour mark, a level of stamina that is fairly difficult to sustain.  I'm not sure that I will do the workout again in its entirety.This is a well-done DVD, and for fans of Ravi and Ana and/or those looking for a intensive core strength-building routine, I would recommend it.
summary: Very long Kundalini practice intensely focuses on the core

reviewText: There were a lot of good points to this DVD. I liked the fact that it was a couple of exercises that worked the abs, then a couple that stretched the abs. It made the workout easier to get through. Some of the exercises didn't seem like yoga to me but more like cardio with sychronized breathing. One review said the music cued you. While that is true, I like that feature. It makes it so I don't have to watch the DVD, but I can just listen to the music and know what I should do (a good thing since this type of yoga should be done with your eyes closed). I do admit that the music selection in this DVD is a little odd and not quite as good as what they usually choose.The reason I gave this exercise four stars is because I didn't feel like I worked my abs very much. I just didn't feel a burn like you normally do in an ab workout and the next day, I wasn't sore at all. I only knocked one star off though because I know you can do more in the poses and make them more difficult. I've only done the workout twice and I usually modify the poses. I'm going to try the DVD again and do the poses as they're shown. Also, the stretches are absolutely wonderful! I'd continue to do this DVD if just for the stretches!Overall, the DVD is ok. I still prefer their Fat Free Yoga - Lose Weight and Feel Great and Ultimate Stretch to this DVD though.

reviewText: This Outstanding DVD will make all of those obstacles and mountains that stand in you way disappear!!!! Do this DVD and create new chapters in your life. Be you, learn to say No when you need to. BE in control of your own life. Flat ABs come pretty quick, this one blows Pilates out of the water. Remember Kundalini Yoga is the Mother of all Yogas. Yoga is where pilates came from, but you want become a vessel for your souls expression no matter how much you do pilates. Let your own personality, love and grace explode into new dimensions a life transforming DVD. After doing this DVD you will be able to "KEEP UP". Thanks Ravi and Ana for the inspiration and most amazing AB workout ever!!!!!Love yourself and buy this DVD today!!!!

reviewText: I am still new to yoga. After trying a few other yoga dvd's(which I did not like very much)I stumbled on to Kundalini yoga with Ravi and Ana. Finding their workouts have been a blessing in my life. With my current health issues these workouts are great for my physical and mental health.Navel Power is absolutely fantastic for not only toning your entire core but teaches you how to work your insides as well. I thank them for including modifications so everyone can use their workouts.I am finding the more I do the workout the more focused and relaxed I become. I always feel more in tune with myself after I am finished with their workouts.I highly recommend Navel Power for anyone who wants to become more in tune with themselves and as a bonus tone your entire core.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is similar in some ways to the now almost legendary Mantra Girl DVDs, though this is even heavier on instruction.Despite the name, this is not a program designed to generate washboard abs, although it is inevitable that they will appear! It is instead designed to generate internal power, and therefore has similarities to some of the practices of qigong. It is this internal power that can affect not just the body, but the mind and subtle systems, as well as having sometimes powerful spiritual effects.I always issue a note of caution: if this program is followed precisely, the effects can be remarkable. This is powerful material, and it is really important to have a discussion with your health care provider before getting started.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I've actually owned this DVD for a long time now, and am only just now realizing that I hadn't reviewed it. I must admit, this particular disc is one I avoid quite often because it's actually rather challenging for me! I like to think I'm pretty fit, and I've been doing yoga in general for a long time, but most hatha yoga doesn't really work your abs (I mean, short boat poses were about all I get from most classes, if anything.So while this disc doesn't make my muscles burn the next day, it's quite hard for me while I'm doing it, and involves a lot of trembling in my stomach and thighs. I've read numerous articles about how exercises of the type (common to pilates) seen in this disc are the best for getting the coveted 'defined abs' look. They require the pulling in of the stomach and the working of the ab muscles via leg motions.Anyway, by the end of Set 1 I am usually done! Skipping Set 2 mostly means avoiding some repetition of exercises, but my workout is still over an hour! I'm still trying to find my inner peace with this workout, still trying to get to a place where I can focus on my breath and 'sat nam' rather than the effort my body is putting forth.We all need naval power in our lives though. I am going to try to get past my resistance to this DVD and make it a bi-weekly, if not weekly routine. It's good for me.
summary: Not hard on your abs? Ow!

reviewText: I am so glad that I found Kundalini Yoga! It is a great workout and feel awesome after each one. This one is a challenge but Ravi and Ana make it easy to quickly progress. I now have 5 of their DVD's in the series so that I could do one every day 5 days a week and after 3 weeks I'm already starting to look toned, have more energy and feel great. I was killing myself working out with little to no results and it's been a real challenge to find something that works with my body, especially with hypothyroidism, but this is it.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I've been doing navel power for a while now and let me tell you it has really helped in so many ways. Besides the visual appeal and lovely music you have a workout that will put you in contact with the belly. You can do tons of crunches and leg lifts, but if you have no connection mentaly to the abdomen you will not achieve satisfying results by doing them. Doing this DVD will help you relax the abdomen, stretch it (thats actually important too) and build strength inside in a non violent way. No compressing the organs and dealing with aches and inflamation later on. You will sure know this is so when you try traditional crunches or leg darts at some other time. Its a long workout, so save some quality time to do it, even if just once a week it will still work for you.

reviewText: I feel like I am getting a real workout from this DVD.  It is one of my favorites.  I have seen their successive DVD's go up to great in production quality, but this one is nice, and is one of the workouts that I do most. I have all of their DVD's. And, the music just keeps getting better; see titles after "A Journey Through the Chakras", and "Dance the Chakras".

reviewText: NAVEL POWER is one of the more rigorous of Raviana's library of Kundalini yoga DVDs, and it's a MUST HAVE. When I'm feeling discouraged and challenged in life, I turn to this DVD, along with their other sweat-fest, WARRIOR.On this DVD (and others) Ravi says that the "fire in the belly" is the key ingredient to transforming yourself. Without it, he says, "Pure transformation is theoretical." SO TRUE. I can readily say that NAVEL POWER and WARRIOR have empowered me in life.Thank you, Ravi and Ana!

reviewText: Not only is this an amazing ab workout, far better than most, but it also takes things a step further and works on the energy center associated with this area of the body. They point out that this is called the "hara," and when it's well developed, you can never be defeated, and can be fearless and have personal power. I love that concept, and I love that Ana Brett & Ravi Singh are able to combine the inner and outer in such a powerful and accessible way. If you are looking for something new to do, and want cut abs, and victory in your life, then you will be overjoyed with this Navel Power DVD!

reviewText: This DVD, part of a series that included Warrior Workout and Ultimate Stretch Yoga Workout, was my first introduction to Ravi Singh and Ana Brett.  I was hooked!  I own most of their other DVDs but I consider this series to be their best.This DVD is truly about the mind/body connection.  This DVD doesn't work your core (aka navel) with traditional exercises.  However, if you really listen to the constant gentle reminders from Ravi to focus on your core, you can feel more powerful and creative.  I love the clean, white background. Ravi is the only one speaking in this DVD; his voice is so soothing and relaxing.What I also love about this DVD:**The warm-up has some unique breathing exercises, not seen in any of their other DVDs.**You pause and meditate briefly after each exercise.  This really helps keep me focused.**Modifications are shown for some of the tougher exercises.**The meditation section is a little under 7 minutes, which is just about right for me to maintain my focus.**Ravi explains the meaning of the words used in the meditations.  When I know what the words mean, it helps me to really concentrate.I highly recommend this DVD for anyone wanting to ignite the fire inside and to feel more powerful.
summary: Really feel that mind - body connection

reviewText: This review will have a two-part format. In the first part, I'll describe the contents of the DVD as well as my thoughts on them. In the second part, I'll say some more general things about Ana and Ravi and kundalini yoga. It seems the negative reviews of their DVDs come mainly from people who didn't know what to expect when ordering kundalini yoga DVDs -- because they ARE a little bit different from what you're used to, if you've only practiced hatha yoga in the past. I am unabashedly an Ana and Ravi fan, but hopefully my evaluation will help you make the correct decision for yourself, even if your opinion happens not to be the same as mine.----------Part I----------Unlike many of Ana and Ravi's DVDs, Navel Power does not have the matrix menu. This means that you will have to have your DVD remote handy to skip sections (e.g., if you want to do only a 30 minute yoga set).  It is a bit difficult to tell when segments start, especially if you are following along and not looking at the screen.  Also, no times for the segments are given in the DVD menu, but I have provided approximate times for each below.  All exercises in this DVD are done equally on both sides of the body.Tune In (2:47): This segment is similar/the same in many of Ana's and Ravi's DVDs; sit cross-legged, focus on your breathing, and chant "ong namo guru dev namo" three times.Warm-Ups (24:44): This is a long warm-up for one of these DVDs, and is properly almost a yoga set in itself.  It consists of the following exercises.*breathing exercise; interlace hands and press into navel, inhale in 4 sniffs and exhale in 1 breath*grind stomach in circles*seated cross-legged, hold your shins and flex your spine back and forth*sitting on your heels, with your hands on your thighs, flex your spine again*a plank from your forearms with your hands interlaced*sitting on your heels, with your hands on your thighs, flex your spine (this time with breath of fire)*sit with your legs and arms extended, inhale/exhale while leaning forward and back*hold one leg up and stretch it in front of you (at a 60 degree angle or so)*inhale slowly up into bridge (the version that's also sometimes called table) and exhale downNavel Power (29:34): This set consists of the following exercises.*slow crunches*sit ups with knees bent (all the way up), with a different breathing pattern than with the crunches*bridge (aka table) with breath of fire*double leg lifts*bicycle exercise with legs only*raise up into cobra, then come back down lying on your stomach; repeat*a stationary modified cobra position with your legs bent up behind you and your feet touching*bow pose*stretch pose (lying with your hands below your rear end, raise head and heels six inches off the floor)*lie on your stomach with your hands and legs extended, hands interlaced, and raise all your limbs off the floor a couple of inches (breath of fire)*standing, put one hand on your sternum and swing the other one out to the side while twisting your torso a little, then repeat on other side*standing, have both arms up, then put one arm down and lean to that side (alternate sides)*with your arms up, hook your thumbs together; lean back, then come forwardNavel Power - Part 2 (16:13): This set consists of the following exercises.  If you're not looking, it's easy to miss the transition between the first and second navel power sets.*repeat crunches*repeat sit-ups*bridge (the one with your shoulders on the ground) or wheel*bicycle exercise but this time, touch opposite elbows to your knees*alternate leg lifts*sat kriya (Google it; it would be rather complicated to explain here if you're unfamiliar)*leaning back and supporting yourself on your elbows, scissor your legs up and down to the rhythm of the breath of fireDeep Relaxation (3:06): This is similar in many of Ravi's and Ana's DVDs. Lie on your back, slow your breathing, and listen to Ravi.  A gong is used rather a lot; this is not a sharp sound, at all, but kind of an extended metallic sound. I don't always like the gong in all of Ana's and Ravi's DVDs, but I think it's OK here.Mantra Meditation (6:23): Note that the normal "closing prayer" segment is part of the same chapter as the meditation on this DVD, so it can't be selected separately from the menu.  The closing prayer is similar to what appears in other Ravi/Ana DVDs.  The mantra is as follows:Har Har Har HarWahay GuruSat NamHar HariYou start by inhaling in 4 breaths, turning your head to alternate sides for each inhale.  Then you face forward to do the mantra.For those of you familiar with Ravi's and Ana's DVDs, this is a fairly old one with Ana demonstrating on a raised platform that's lighted from within and a fake clouds background.  Only Ravi narrates, while Ana demonstrates the poses and movements.  The camera moves some but it's not as distracting as in some of the newer (blonde Ana) DVDs, and you don't miss anything important.  Occasionally, the camera picks up the edge of the set and you can see audio-visual equipment, but most of the time, there's a decent illusion of space.  The music is mostly instrumental and is appropriately-paced.There is a LOT of content on this DVD and that's great.  However, I wish the individual segments were broken up into smaller pieces for a more customizable workout (I like to do about 30 minutes of yoga each morning).  I also wish it was easier to tell when each segment was over (kundalini yoga is typically done with the eyes closed and you miss the titles that flash by at the beginning of each set).  This is especially important since there's no programmable matrix menu.  (However, if you keep this review in mind, you'll know what's the last exercise in each case.)If you have done the Solar Power DVD that Ana and Ravi have put out, not to worry - there is not much in the way of duplicated content.One warning: sometimes doing too much bridge or table every day, can cause my wrists to hurt a bit. So if you have wrist issues, take it easy with the bridge/table pose, or do the modification where your shoulders are on the ground.I have about 2/3 of Ana's and Ravi's DVDs, and I think this one is solid. I would probably suggest this for intermediate to advanced users. Ana and Ravi do offer some suggestions for modifications of certain poses. I simply can't do wheel, for example, and I have the aforementioned wrist issues that keep me from doing too much bridge/table.  Finally, don't forget -- you don't have to keep up with Ana. Work at your own pace.Just to be clear, I think the yoga sets in this DVD are quite valuable. I particularly like the emphasis on ALL parts of the abdominals.  Sure, there are crunches.  But there's also a lot of work on the back, which is quite important for posture and to have balanced muscles.  There's also work on the obliques, the lower abs, and the deep abdominals.  In my case, I don't hurt afterwards (like I would after Ab Ripper X from P90X).  But, if you haven't exercised your abs in awhile, you may feel it the next day.I'd probably rate this 4.5 stars because there was a little repetition and because of the lack of times/matrix menu, but I'll round up to 5.----------Part II----------Now, on to a more general discussion of kundalini yoga in general, and Ana's and Ravi's DVDs in particular. (I intend to include a version of this in all my reviews of Ana's and Ravi's DVDs.)Most of the yoga that people are familiar with falls under the umbrella of hatha yoga. Perhaps you've done a series of static poses, or some vinyasa/flow yoga. Kundalini yoga is not exactly like either of these, although Ana's and Ravi's DVDs do incorporate elements of hatha yoga (e.g., this DVD has bow pose in it). However, kundalini yoga is also what I would consider to be a very active form of yoga, consisting of some repeated movements and a lot more work with the breath than you may be used to. It can be difficult to keep up with at first, but can be very rewarding if you stick with it. If you are bored of holding static poses all the time, or if you want a bit more movement but hate vinyasa (sorry, but I am not a fan of flow yoga), kundalini might really work well for you. And, as I said earlier, use the modifications Ana and Ravi discuss if you need to use them. Yes, Ana is fit (and this makes her an excellent demonstrator for the poses), but this is not a competition. Don't strain yourself, and don't try to keep up with her. Just try to improve a little bit every time!Kundalini yoga also involves a lot of meditation. Sometimes this is quiet and involves breathing either in a sitting position or lying down, occasionally with your hands in a mudra (hand position). Sometimes it involves chanting a mantra. This DVD contains a fair amount of mantra chanting - there's the chanting segment, as well as the opening and closing segments. Whenever there are mantras, Ana and Ravi tell you what they mean. If you are uncomfortable with mantras for religious reasons, check out Ana's and Ravi's website (can't post links in reviews but they're easy to find through Google) for alternatives and use the matrix menu or your DVD remote to skip the chant. (I happen to like the chants, but that's just me.)With respect to calorie-burning, this is probably not the sort of program that will make you shed a ton of weight. What this DVD is particularly good for is strengthening your core and improving your posture. But kundalini yoga works on your inner self as well as your outer self, and so some parts are a little less "active" than others. For my own part, I still do plenty of pretty intense cardio at other times of the day.Ana's outfits are a bit skimpy, but certainly nothing less than you would see at the beach. And the reason she dresses like she does is so that you can really see her performing the movements and asanas. That way you know exactly how to position yourself for maximum benefit. (Most of the time, kundalini yoga is done with the eyes closed, anyway.) There is not a lot in the way of initial instruction in this DVD. If you are familiar with Ana's and Ravi's work, you can jump right in. But if you are new to kundalini yoga, watch it first. Observe Ana, listen to the cues, make sure you understand. You'll be glad for the lack of excessive instruction later -- you don't want to be told on the 20th time you do a DVD how to do bridge; you know it by this point!Fewer health claims are made in this DVD compared to Ana's and Ravi's other DVDs. I find that Ana and Ravi are quite accurate when it comes to muscular and skeletal issues. At any rate, certainly don't use yoga as a substitute for seeing the doctor. But doing a routine like this isn't likely to hurt you or make your health condition worse (as long as you PACE YOURSELF).If you are struggling with a pose, Ravi and Ana are very accessible and quite nice. They have contact information on their website (the URL is on the DVD case) and usually get back to you in a couple of days. They also have a monthly e-mail newsletter that I enjoy.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I purchased this DVD not so much for keeping in shape, but for building a strong navel center. Today was the first time I put on the Navel Power DVD, and I was completely mesmerized with the background music from the word go! It's the kind of music that makes you (at least me) wanna do some yoga, what a coincidence :) The workout itself is really great!!  But here's the thing - I really feel that this DVD is geared towards those who have some experience with yoga or are really fit, with great stamina.I am kind of like a beginner, I mean this is not my first Ravi-Ana DVD, but admittedly I have been out of practice for a bit. Well, as a result I found the Navel sets really hard. I am certain that if I persevere with this DVD, with time I will get the hang of the poses and hold them for as long as Ana does. But I think I will re-acclimatize myself to yoga with other Ravi-Ana DVDs and then graduate to Navel Power. Maybe, that will make for a smoother transition.
Title: N/A
